payload.instructions:
# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm
- If you want to boot the kernel, the shell has a variety of commands (including shutdown) - which you can use to stop the kernel and return to your thinking

Thanks!

content.text:
<user_instructions>

# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm
- If you want to boot the kernel, the shell has a variety of commands (including shutdown) - which you can use to stop the kernel and return to your thinking

Thanks!



</user_instructions>

## My request for Codex:
Time to fix an old bug:  our mouse 'jumps' back sometimes - for example, if you move to the left, the mouse reappears back towards the right where it just was.

We fixed this previously but I forgot to save the code - i believe the issue was with freezing interrupts for the mouse whilst we process the packet or something

payload.text:
**Examining interrupt enabling during mouse event processing**

I'm thinking through how disabling interrupts before calling `mouse_process_byte` causes it to keep interrupts off during logging and listener calls, which may hurt responsiveness. I see that to avoid race conditions, interrupts must stay disabled between reading a byte and safely appending it to the packet, but enabling interrupts for longer operations like event dispatch is preferable. To fix this, I'm considering restructuring the code to separate packet building (done with interrupts disabled) from event dispatch (done with interrupts enabled), possibly by splitting `mouse_process_byte` or adding helper functions. This way, we ensure atomic packet updates while keeping interrupts enabled during longer callback work, balancing correctness and responsiveness.

**Proposing interrupt-safe mouse polling with nested saves**

Im considering disabling interrupts around each byte read-and-process in `mouse_poll` using `mouse_irq_save` and `mouse_irq_restore` to prevent race conditions with the IRQ handler and other contexts. This approach preserves the order of bytes processed without requiring major restructuring and accepts that interrupts stay disabled during packet processing just like in the IRQ handler path. It looks like a clean fix that aligns with existing behavior and avoids concurrency bugs while still allowing logging and listener calls safely.

summary.text:
**Examining interrupt enabling during mouse event processing**

I'm thinking through how disabling interrupts before calling `mouse_process_byte` causes it to keep interrupts off during logging and listener calls, which may hurt responsiveness. I see that to avoid race conditions, interrupts must stay disabled between reading a byte and safely appending it to the packet, but enabling interrupts for longer operations like event dispatch is preferable. To fix this, I'm considering restructuring the code to separate packet building (done with interrupts disabled) from event dispatch (done with interrupts enabled), possibly by splitting `mouse_process_byte` or adding helper functions. This way, we ensure atomic packet updates while keeping interrupts enabled during longer callback work, balancing correctness and responsiveness.

**Proposing interrupt-safe mouse polling with nested saves**

Im considering disabling interrupts around each byte read-and-process in `mouse_poll` using `mouse_irq_save` and `mouse_irq_restore` to prevent race conditions with the IRQ handler and other contexts. This approach preserves the order of bytes processed without requiring major restructuring and accepts that interrupts stay disabled during packet processing just like in the IRQ handler path. It looks like a clean fix that aligns with existing behavior and avoids concurrency bugs while still allowing logging and listener calls safely.

payload.text:
**Reviewing mouse_irq_save/restore usage**

Im carefully checking how mouse_irq_save and mouse_irq_restore are used in the loop to ensure interrupts are managed correctly when processing mouse and keyboard data. The logic handles sequential bytes and breaks appropriately when keyboard data is detected, avoiding premature consumption of mouse data, but Im considering if running tests or a diff check is worthwhile for verification.

payload.text:
**Analyzing interrupt handling edge cases**

Im carefully reasoning through how interrupts are disabled and restored in `mouse_poll` during various break and continue scenarios, especially considering keyboard data and mouse data handling. Im weighing the impact on system latency and responsiveness, comparing interrupt-driven and polling paths, and confirming that interrupts are properly restored to avoid deadlock or degraded behavior. Im also reflecting on concurrency concerns with SMP systems and debating the need for testing given the minor change.

payload.text:
**Summarizing final message content**

I'll prepare a clear bullet-point summary explaining the mouse poll fix with precise file and line references, describe the bug and fix effect, note tests not run, and suggest rebuild and QEMU verification steps.

summary.text:
**Summarizing final message content**

I'll prepare a clear bullet-point summary explaining the mouse poll fix with precise file and line references, describe the bug and fix effect, note tests not run, and suggest rebuild and QEMU verification steps.

payload.message:
**Mouse Poll Fix**
- `mouse_poll` now masks interrupts around each byte read so the PS/2 packet buffer is updated atomically regardless of preemption; this prevents other contexts (e.g., timer-driven task switches) from consuming later bytes first and making the cursor snap back (`src/drivers/mouse.c:209`).
- The loop restores the captured interrupt state on every exit path, so keyboard bytes are still left for the keyboard driver while mouse bytes are serialized before dispatch (`src/drivers/mouse.c:213`).

Not run: kernel build/boot. Suggest rebuilding (`make`) and giving the pointer a workout in QEMU (`make run-hdd`) to confirm the jump-back is gone.

content.text:
**Mouse Poll Fix**
- `mouse_poll` now masks interrupts around each byte read so the PS/2 packet buffer is updated atomically regardless of preemption; this prevents other contexts (e.g., timer-driven task switches) from consuming later bytes first and making the cursor snap back (`src/drivers/mouse.c:209`).
- The loop restores the captured interrupt state on every exit path, so keyboard bytes are still left for the keyboard driver while mouse bytes are serialized before dispatch (`src/drivers/mouse.c:213`).

Not run: kernel build/boot. Suggest rebuilding (`make`) and giving the pointer a workout in QEMU (`make run-hdd`) to confirm the jump-back is gone.

payload.text:
**Analyzing mouse input race conditions**

I'm reconsidering the interrupt disabling strategy around mouse event handling and g_listener calls, suspecting that interrupts re-enabled during g_listener might cause race issues. Im exploring if overflow bits or sign handling in PS/2 packets might explain cursor jumps, and also whether polling and IRQ contexts interfere, despite nested disables. Next, I want to verify how video_irq_save handles interrupts since its invoked around mouse event updates.

summary.text:
**Analyzing mouse input race conditions**

I'm reconsidering the interrupt disabling strategy around mouse event handling and g_listener calls, suspecting that interrupts re-enabled during g_listener might cause race issues. Im exploring if overflow bits or sign handling in PS/2 packets might explain cursor jumps, and also whether polling and IRQ contexts interfere, despite nested disables. Next, I want to verify how video_irq_save handles interrupts since its invoked around mouse event updates.

payload.text: **Analyzing mouse interrupt and polling race conditions**

**Investigating interrupt handling and polling interaction**

I'm considering how `mouse_poll` reading data without sending PIC EOI might cause issues, especially with pending IRQs; Im also wondering if re-enabling interrupts between packets introduces race conditions, and whether masking keyboard IRQ during mouse byte processing could help prevent data misrouting. Theres a lot to unpack here!

Theres a lot to unpack here!

payload.text: **Analyzing mouse interrupt handling and event ordering**

**Evaluating interrupt disabling strategies for mouse packet processing**

I'm thinking through whether to keep interrupts disabled during the entire mouse_process_byte functionincluding while calling the event listenerto avoid out-of-order event handling. This could prevent pointer jumps caused by recursive IRQs, though it risks blocking other critical interrupts. A possible compromise is disabling only the mouse IRQ line (IRQ12) instead of global interrupts, balancing responsiveness and event order. I'll explore this approach, as it might replicate the users previous patch more precisely.

summary.text: **Analyzing mouse interrupt handling and event ordering**

A possible compromise is disabling only the mouse IRQ line (IRQ12) instead of global interrupts, balancing responsiveness and event order. I'll explore this approach, as it might replicate the users previous patch more precisely.

payload.text:
**Analyzing interrupt handling and listener ordering**

I'm reasoning through restructuring `mouse_process_byte` to keep interrupts disabled during logging and listener calls by moving `mouse_irq_restore` after them, using goto labels to ensure all paths restore interrupts properly, while considering reentrancy, nested interrupt disabling, and side effects on responsiveness and video event handling.

I'm carefully examining how interrupts are managed around the `g_listener` calls in different contexts, especially focusing on `mouse_process_byte` when invoked by poll or IRQ paths. I want to confirm that keeping interrupts disabled through the entire processing sequenceincluding during `g_listener`preserves correct interrupt states and doesn't introduce side effects during CLI idle or video usage. Next, I'll verify the repo state with `git status` before finalizing the message.

payload.message:
Mouse packets are now handled atomically so we never reapply stale deltas before finishing the current one.  
- `src/drivers/mouse.c:133-223` keeps interrupts masked from the moment a byte enters `mouse_process_byte` until after we finish logging and call the registered listener. Previously we restored IF just before dispatching, so a fresh IRQ could preempt and feed the next packet out of order, making the cursor snap back to an older x position; now the entire packet (and its listener work) runs as one critical section.  
- The same file also wraps each iteration of `mouse_poll` in the same `mouse_irq_save`/`mouse_irq_restore` pair so draining buffered AUX bytes cant interleave with the IRQ handler, preventing partial packets from being seen twice or raced by the keyboard reader.

Not run: kernel build/boot. Recommend `make` followed by `make run-hdd`, then drag the pointer around long sweeps in both directions to confirm the jump-back is gone.

content.text:
Mouse packets are now handled atomically so we never reapply stale deltas before finishing the current one.  
- `src/drivers/mouse.c:133-223` keeps interrupts masked from the moment a byte enters `mouse_process_byte` until after we finish logging and call the registered listener. Previously we restored IF just before dispatching, so a fresh IRQ could preempt and feed the next packet out of order, making the cursor snap back to an older x position; now the entire packet (and its listener work) runs as one critical section.  
- The same file also wraps each iteration of `mouse_poll` in the same `mouse_irq_save`/`mouse_irq_restore` pair so draining buffered AUX bytes cant interleave with the IRQ handler, preventing partial packets from being seen twice or raced by the keyboard reader.

Not run: kernel build/boot. Recommend `make` followed by `make run-hdd`, then drag the pointer around long sweeps in both directions to confirm the jump-back is gone.
